item.name: Upgraded to new frameworks/libraries versions
item.description: JUnit 4, Spring 3.1, Spring Security 3.1, Wicket 6

item.name: Two-phase user register
item.description: Aimed to avoid problems with user registration. When a subsystem registers a user in Superfly and then fails to register them locally, it made repeated registration impossible because Superfly already had such a user. Now, after subsystem registers a user in Superfly AND locally, it calls second phase call making an incomplete user (created on phase 1) complete. Incomplete user allows to be registered again.

item.name: Impersonation support
item.description: It is now possible to get user's roles+actions without checking password. This may be useful for impersonation functionality.

item.name: Redirect-based Single Sign-on functionality
item.description: Single sign-on option based on redirects. This allows user to login just once and then access all his subsystems with no additional authentication.

item.name: Single Sign-out
item.description: This feature allows to destroy an SSO session which was established using redirect-based Single Sign-on login process.

item.name: Single Sign-on forms are skinnable
item.description: A URL to subsystem-side CSS may be specified in Subsystem settings. This CSS file will be used by Superfly when a user logs into that subsystem via Redirect-based Single Sign-on process. This allows subsystem to customize login forms look.

item.name: HttpClient timeouts
item.description: All HttpClient timeouts (connectionTimeout, soTimeout, connectionManagerTimeout) are configurable so no eternal freezes occur anymore. This is fixed both for internal server code (notifications) and client libraries.

item.name: SMTP servers
item.description: Any number of SMTP servers may be configured. They will be used for sending emails to users (like email with OTP table). SMTP server may be specified for a subsystem.

item.name: Remote editing and password/OTP table resetting
item.description: It's now possible to edit a user and reset their password and OTP table via an SSOService.

item.name: PGP Public keys
item.description: PGP Public keys may be stored for users and be used to sign materials which are sent by a Superfly server.

item.name: HOTP tables via e-mail
item.description: Now, HOTP tables may be sent via email to their owners. Table is encrypted with user's PGP public key.

item.name: PCI-DSS requirements
item.description: Superfly is modified to comply to PCI-DSS requirements. See further tasks for details.

item.name: Password encryption
item.description: Passwords in database are encrypted. Salt is supported. All MesageDigest algorithms available via JRE are supported for hashing.

item.name: Password expiration
item.description: Passwords may be configured to be expired with time.

item.name: Accounts suspension
item.description: User accounts may be configured to be suspended after a period of inactivity.

item.name: PCI-DSS password restrictions
item.description: Restrictions like minimal password length, mixed letters and digits, not matching to recently used passwords may be configured to be applied.

item.name: Password reset
item.description: Password reset may be carried out in accordance to PCI-DSS.

item.name: Two-factor authentication
item.description: Two-factor authentication is supported on spring-security side by new module structure for authentication workflow. Server-side, infrastructure for One-Time Passwords is created and ready for providers to be plugged in.

item.name: Logging
item.description: Logging of operations with system objects.

item.name: UI enhancements
item.description: Actions are sorted by name in lists. Filters are made sticky.

item.name: Local mode
item.description: Local mode for Spring Security integration allows to develop your application more easily with no requirement to interact with a Superfly server

item.name: Spring 3.0 support
item.description: Some internal classes are changed to work with Spring 3.0. superfly-spring-security artifact now works with Spring Security 3.0, while legacy artifact working with Spring Security 2.0.x was moved to superfly-spring-security-2.0.

item.name: Jira integration
item.description: It's possible to configure Jira to use Superfly as a security provider.

item.name: UI enhancements
item.description: UI is made a bit more friendly.

item.name: UI
item.description: UI for subsystems, users, roles, actions management

item.name: Remote login
item.description: Login from subsystems is implemented

item.name: Actions from subsystem
item.description: Subsystem is able to send its actions to the Superfly server

item.name: Spring Security integration
item.description: To use Superfly security (authentication/authorization) in your application you only need to use a Superfly module for Spring Security

item.name: SSL integration
item.description: Subsystem may be authenticated to the Superfly server using a client SSL authentication

item.name: Demo application
item.description: All features (including Spring security integration and SSL integration) are demonstrated by a Demo application
